title: 105_hr4863
content: Disagreements or conflicts between agency heads or between OMB and any agency that cannot be resolved by the Administrator of OIRA shall be resolved by the President or a designee of the President. An agency must not publish any regulatory action subject to review until the Administrator of OIRA waives or completes review, or the time period expires without further consideration. If requirements are not met, the agency can request Presidential consideration through OIRA. Upon receipt of a request, the Administrator of OIRA notifies the Advisers. The guidelines and time period for publication of regulatory actions requiring Presidential consideration apply. SEC. 9. AGENCY AUTHORITY. This Act does not displace agencies' authority or responsibilities as authorized by law. SEC. 10. JUDICIAL REVIEW. This Act does not affect judicial review of agency action. It is intended to improve internal government management and does not create enforceable rights against the United States. SEC. 11. DEFINITIONS. The term "Advisers" in this Act refers to regulatory policy advisers to the President, including various officials such as the Director of OMB and the Chair of the Council of Economic Advisers. The term "agency" in this Act refers to any authority of the United States that is considered an agency under title 44, excluding independent regulatory agencies. The term "Director" refers to the Director of OMB. The term "regulation" or "rule" refers to an agency's regulatory actions. The term "regulation" or "rule" refers to an agency statement of general applicability and future effect intended to have the force of law, designed to implement, interpret, or prescribe law or policy, or describe agency procedure or practice requirements. It excludes regulations issued through formal rulemaking, those related to military or foreign affairs functions, and regulations limited to agency actions. The term "regulatory action" refers to any substantive action by an agency that leads to the promulgation of a final rule or regulation. A "significant regulatory action" is one likely to result in a rule with an annual economic impact of $100 million or more. A significant regulatory action is defined as one that is likely to result in a rule with an annual economic impact of $100 million or more, or adversely affect the economy, productivity, competition, jobs, environment, public health, safety, or government entities. It may also create inconsistencies with actions taken by other agencies, alter budgetary impacts, or raise novel legal or policy issues.
